title: \text{Eta Values at imaginary quadratic points in } \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3}i)

eta_values.explanation: Use of modular polynomial $\Phi_2(X,Y)$ with $j(\frac{-1+\sqrt{3}\textit{i}}{2})=0$ gives $j(\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=54000$. Then equation (3) gives $u(\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=\frac{13}{512}-\frac{15\sqrt{3}}{1024}$  . Finally use $\eta(\sqrt{3}\textit{i})$ value in equation (3).

Modular polynomial $\Phi_2(X,Y)$ with $j(\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=54000$ gives $j(2\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=141790500+818626500\sqrt{3}$. Then equation (3) gives $u(2\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=\frac{-15\sqrt{3}}{8}-\frac{1667}{512}+\frac{5445\sqrt{6}}{4096}+\frac{9405\sqrt{2}}{4096}$  . Finally use  $\eta(4\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=\sqrt{2}(5445\sqrt{6}+9405\sqrt{2}-7680\sqrt{3}-13336)^{\frac{1}{24}}\eta(2\sqrt{3}\textit{i})$ and $\eta(2\sqrt{3}\textit{i})$ value in equation (3).

Modular polynomial $\Phi_2(X,Y)$  with $j(\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=54000$ gives $j(\frac{\sqrt{3}\textit{i}}{2})=141790500-818626500\sqrt{3}$. Then equation (3) gives $u(2\sqrt{3}\textit{i})=\frac{13}{2}-\frac{15\sqrt{3}}{4}$. Finally, use $\eta(\frac{\sqrt{3}\textit{i}}{2})=(\frac{13}{2}-\frac{15\sqrt{3}}{4})^{-\frac{1}{24}}\eta(\sqrt{3}\textit{i})$ and equation (2)

Modular polynomial $\Phi_2(X,Y)$   gives $j(\frac{\sqrt{3}\textit{i}}{4})=−1160733998424384000\sqrt{3}+2010450259344609000+820762881440077125\sqrt{6}− 1421603011620136125\sqrt{2}$. Then equation (3) gives $u(\frac{\sqrt{3}\textit{i}}{2})=\frac{282645\sqrt{6}}{4}-99930\sqrt{3}-\frac{489555\sqrt{2}}{4}+173084$. Finally, use equations (2) and $u$ value
